title-group.article-title: Silicon-containing oligomeric poly(amides) with phthalimidyl-amide side groups: synthesis, characterization and thermal studies

contrib-group.aff: Facultad de Química, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Santiago, Chile

author-notes.corresp: Luis H. Tagle, Facultad de Química, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, P.O. Box 306, Santiago, Chile Email: ltagle@uc.cl

abstract.p: Oligomeric poly(amide)s (PAs) were synthesized from monomeric diacids, which were obtained from phthalic anhydride and the amino acid glycine, l-alanine, l-phenylalanine, l-valine, l-leucine, l-isoleucine and p-aminobenzoic acid. The phthalimidyl acids (IA-1 to IA-7) reacted with 5-amino-isophthalic acid in order to obtain the monomeric diacids (1-7). Furthermore, the monomeric diacid 8 was obtained by direct reaction between phthalic anhydride and 5-amino-isophthalic acid. The isophthalic acid derivatives were reacted with bis(4-aminophenyl)diphenylsilane in order to obtain the PAs. Monomers and polymers were characterized by infrared and 1H-, 13C- and 29Si-NMR spectroscopy, elemental analysis and, when necessary, optical rotation. The results were in agreement with the proposed structures. The yields were generally good, but the η inh values were low, indicating that the polymers were of oligomeric nature, namely, a chain of moderate molecular weight. The polymers were soluble in polar aprotic solvents and some of them were soluble in m-cresol and tetrahydrofuran. The glass transition temperatures (T g) values were obtained by differential scanning calorimetry, showing, in general, a decrease in value when the volume of the side chain of the amino acid moiety was increased. The thermal stability of the polymers was determined by dynamic thermogravimetry, showing good values of thermal decomposition temperatures (TDT), especially for those with aromatic residue in the amino acid, and for PA without amino acid. For PAs in which the side chain of the amino acid was larger, the TDT values were lower, probably due to the lack of symmetry and the length of the side chain, both of which have influence on the thermal stability.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Poly(amide)s and poly(imide)s are considered to be two important types of condensation polymers due to their large number of applications and thermal stability. However, many of the applications of these kinds of polymers are limited by the high transition temperature (T g) values and the low solubility pattern that they present. Many efforts have been made to obtain poly(amide)s with good solubility and processability, while maintaining the thermal stability. Some of these include the introduction of flexible units, 1 meta-substituted aromatic groups 2,3 and non-planar groups in the polymeric structure. 4 These modifications break the symmetry of the polymeric chain and minimize the hydrogen bonds, consequently increasing the solubility. 5

Another option, the poly(imide-amide)s, have been developed as alternative materials because they can offer the high thermal stability of the poly(imide)s and the processability of the poly(amide)s. 6 Furthermore, in this sense, the introduction of bulky and large pendant groups into the main chain can improve the solubility when flexible bonds are included in the repeating unit. 7 –9

Alternatively, the introduction of chiral and flexible units in the repeating unit, in order to obtain optically active polymers, can perform as key basic materials for well defined high performance polymers. 10 Recently, Mallakpour et al. have published an interesting review about optically active condensation polymers, in which they mention that ’the synthesis of chiral polymers containing amino acids is a subject of much interest, since a high degree of amino acid functionality can lead to polymers with increased solubility and the ability to form secondary structures‘. 11 The same authors have also described the synthesis of poly(amides) derived from chiral isophthalic acids, which have a phthalimide function and amino acid residue as side chain with different diamines. The resulting optically active poly(amides) were insoluble in several organic solvents and showed good thermal stability. 12 –14

It has also been reported that the use of α-amino acids as building units for degradable polymers offer advantages such as chemical functionality (hydroxy, amine, carbonyl, thiol), enhancing of thermal and mechanical properties, plus several other biological properties. 15

On the other hand, the introduction of Si atoms in the main chain implies the introduction of polar bonds due to the polarity of the Si-C bond, caused by the difference in electronegativity of these atoms. As a consequence of the ionic character of the Si-C bond in relation to the C-C bond, most of the silicon containing aromatic polymers can maintain or increase thermal stability and improve solubility, properties that facilitate the processing of these materials. 6,16 –18 In addition, Bruma et al. has suggested that the incorporation of Si atoms into the polymeric chain could promote electron transport due to conjugation between d orbitals of the Si atoms and π orbitals of the aromatic rings. 16

Continuing the authors’ work on the synthesis, characterization and thermal studies of silicon-containing polymers, the synthesis of new poly(amides) derived from isophthalic acids bonded to a phthalimide group through several natural optically active l-α-amino acids, glycine and p-aminobenzoic acid, and a wholly aromatic silicon-containing diamine is described herein. These structural changes can promote good solubility in common organic solvents and suitable thermal properties to the new polymeric materials. Polymers were characterized by elemental analysis, optical activity and IR and NMR spectroscopy, including 29Si-NMR, and also by thermal properties (glass transition temperature T g, and thermal decomposition temperature TDT). The results were related to the structure of the polymers, with special attention to the amino acid residue.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Glycine, l-alanine, l-phenylalanine, l-valine, l-leucine, l-isoleucine, p-amino-benzoic acid, 5-amino-isophthalic acid and phthalic anhydride were obtained from Aldrich Chemical (Milwaukee, WI, USA). The purity of reagents and solvents was checked by 1H- and 13C-NMR spectroscopy, and used without further purification. All other reagents and solvents were purchased commercially as analytical grade and used without further purification.

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p: The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer (Fremont CA) 1310 spectrophotometer over the range of 450–4000 cm−1. The 1H-, 13C- and 29Si-NMR spectra were carried out on a 400 MHz instrument (Bruker AC-200) using DMSO-d 6, CDCl3 or acetone-d 6 as solvents and tetramethylsilane (TMS) as internal standard. Viscosimetric measurements were made in a Desreux-Bischof type dilution viscosimeter at 25°C (c = 0.3 g dL−1). The T g values were obtained with a Mettler-Toledo (Greifensee, Switzerland) DSC 821 calorimetric system (20°C min−1 under N2 flow) after the second heating run. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in a Mettler (Switzerland) TA-3000 calorimetric system equipped with a TC-10A processor, and a TG-50 thermobalance with a Mettler MT5 microbalance. Samples of 6–10 mg were placed in a platinum sample holder, and the thermogravimetric measurements were carried out between 30 and 800°C with a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under N2 flow. Specific rotations were measured in an optical activity automatic polarimeter, Model AA-5 at 17°C. Elemental analyses were made on a Fisons EA 1108-CHNS-O equipment.

sec.title: Monomers
sec.p: Imido-acids (IA): phthalimidyl-acetic acid (IA-1), 2-phthalimidyl-propionic acid (IA-2), 19 2-phthalimidyl-3-phenyl-propionic acid (IA-3), 20 2-phthalimidyl-3-methyl-butanoic acid (IA-4), 21 2-phthalimidyl-4-methyl-pentanoic acid (IA-5), 12 2-phthalimidyl-3-methyl-pentanoic acid (IA-6), 13 and 4-phthalimidyl-benzoic acid (IA-7), were obtained from phthalic anhydride and the respective amino acid, according to a general procedure in which the phthalic anhydride (0.05 mol) was mixed with the amino acid (0.05 mol) in 50 mL of acetic acid and stirred for 4 h. Then the mixture was refluxed for four hours and the acetic acid removed under vacuum. The residue was poured in 50 mL of 10% HCl and the solid was filtered, washed several times with water, dried under vacuum until constant weight was achieved, and characterized (Scheme 1).

Imido-amide-diacids: 5-(phthalimidyl-acetylamino)-isophthalic acid (1), 5-(2-phthalimidyl-propionylamino)-isophthalic acid (2), 19 5-(2-phthalimidyl-3-phenyl-propionylamino)-isophthalic acid (3), 20 5-(2-phthalimidyl-3-methyl-butanoylamino)-isophthalic acid (4), 21 5-(2-phthalimidyl-4-methyl-pentanoylamino)-isophthalic acid (5), 12 5-(2-phthalimidyl-3-methyl-pentanoylamino)-isophthalic acid (6), 13 and 5-(4-phthalimidyl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid (7) were obtained from the phthalimidyl acids according to a general procedure, in which the imide acid (3.575 mmol) was mixed with 10 mL of thionyl chloride in order to obtain the acid chloride, which reacted with 3.575 mmol of 5-amino isophthalic acid in 4.6 mL of N, N-dimethylacetamide, and was heated at 80°C for 30 min. Then 0.19 mL of triethylamine was added and the mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 8 h. The mixture was poured in 10% HCl, and the solid filtered, washed with water and dried until constant weight was achieved (Scheme 1). The diacid 5-phthalimidyl-isophthalic (8) was obtained by the reaction between phthalic anhydride and 5-amino-isophthalic acid (Scheme 2). All compounds were characterized by infrared and 1H- and 13C-NMR.
The diamine bis(4-aminophenyl)diphenylsilane was obtained from 4-bromo-N, N-bis(trimethylsilyl)aniline and diphenyldichlorosilane, according to a reported procedure. 22

sec.title: Polymer synthesis
sec.p: Poly(amides) (PIA 1–8) were synthesized according to the following general procedure. 23,24 In a typical polymerization process, 0.545 mmol of the monomeric diacid is mixed with 0.545 mmol of the diamine, 240 mg of anydrous CaCl2, 0.280 mL of triphenylphosphite (TPP), 1.2 mL of pyridine and 1.8 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The mixture is heated at 110–120°C for 3 h and then poured into methanol at room temperature. The polymer is filtered, washed and dried under vacuum until constant weight is achieved. All polymers were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, 1H-, 13C- and 29Si-NMR.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Phthalimidyl acids (IA-1 to IA-7) were obtained from phthalic anhydride and the respective amino acid, and the monomeric isophthalic diacids (1–7) from the phthalimidyl acids and 5-aminoisophthalic acid, according to the described procedures, and characterized by spectroscopic methods. The results were in agreement with those reported in the literature (Scheme 1). 12,13,19 –21 Monomeric diacid 8 was obtained directly by the reaction between phthalic anhydride and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (Scheme 2). The diamine bis(4-aminophenyl)diphenylsilane was obtained from 4-bromo-N, N-bis(trimethylsilyl)aniline according to the literature. 22 All the compounds were characterized by IR and 1H- and 13C-NMR spectroscopy, and the results were in agreement with the proposed structures.

Poly(amide)s (PAs) were obtained from the monomeric diacids (1–8) and the silicon-containing diamine according to the triphenyl phosphite method with anhydrous CaCl2 and pyridine in NMP at 110–120°C for 3 h. 23,24 The PAs were precipitated in methanol, filtered, washed and dried under vacuum until constant weight was achieved. All polymers were characterized by IR, 1H-, 13C- and 29Si-NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. The results were in agreement with the proposed structures and have already been summarized in the previous section.

It was possible to observe a signal at about −15 ppm in all polymers in the 29Si-spectra, corresponding to the Si atom bonded to four phenyl rings, which has been described in polymers synthesized from different types of bifunctional monomers containing these groups. 24
–30 The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra showed the characteristic pattern for the imide and amide functions (Figure 1). In all spectra, it was possible to observe a broad absorption at 3369–3462 cm−1 for the amidic N–H stretching vibration. The carbonyl group region clearly showed one or two peaks associated with symmetric imide C=O vibration at about 1710 cm−1 and one peak for amide C=O (1650 cm−1 approximately). Figure 2 shows a typical series of NMR spectra taken at 19°C in DMSO-d6 solution for PA-5.

sec.p: Table 1 shows the solubility of the polymers in different solvents. With the exception of PA-3, polymers were soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as DMSO and NMP. Some of them were completely or partially soluble in dimethylacetamide (DMAc), dimethylformamide (DMF) or m-cresol. Finally, only PA-1, PA-4 and PA-8 were soluble in tetrahydrofuran (THF). This table also shows that all samples were insoluble in CHCl3. In general, the increase in solubility towards other solvents such as m-cresol and THF could be due to the meta structure of the diacid, the amino acid moiety and the polarity of the Si–C bond of the diamine.

sec.p: PAs derived from l-amino acids showed optical activity and the values are summarized in Table 2. PA-3, derived from l-phenylalanine, was insoluble in all solvents, including the polar aprotic solvents, and therefore, it was impossible to obtain the NMR spectra. The FT-IR (KBr) spectrum and elemental analysis were used for its characterization.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the yields, specific rotation and η inh values obtained for all polymers. In general, the yields were good, with the exception of PA-7, which was derived from p-aminobenzoic acid, and PA-8, which was obtained from the diacid derived from phthalic anhydride and 4-aminoisophthalic acid and the diamine. These two polymers were prepared in order to compare their behavior with those obtained from PAs derived from the l-amino acids. Most probably, the lower yield obtained for these two PAs is related to the higher structural rigidity of the diacid moiety, which could diminish the mobility of chain in growth. On the other hand, all η inh values were low and probably are indicative of oligomeric species and/or chains of moderate molecular weight.

Table 3 shows the T g values for PAs. All PAs have the same main chain, and the differences are in the amino acid moiety of the side chain. Consequently, the changes in the T g values can be attributed to these groups, in the sense that at larger volumes and greater flexibility of the side groups, the T g values will be lower. The highest T g value was obtained for PA-1, derived from glycine, which had only a hydrogen atom as side group, and therefore, the polymer was symmetric. In all cases, when the side chain was increased, the T g values were lower. The behavior of PA-2, derived from l-alanine, is anomalous and the T g value should be higher with respect to PA-4 derived from l-valine. For PA-6, PA-5 and PA-3, as the sizes or volumes of the side groups of amino acids increase, the T g values decrease. These latter three PAs showed very low T g values (35–20°C). As was expected, PA-5 and PA-6, derived from isomeric amino acids, showed practically the same value. A similar behavior for poly(methacrylate)s with cyclic rings as side groups was described, showing that when the cycle size was increased, the T g values decreased significantly. 31

caption.p: Glass transition temperatures and thermal decomposition temperatures of the poly(amides)

fn.p: *Temperature at which the poly(amides) had lost 10% of weight.

sec.p: PA-7, derived from p-amino benzoic acid with an aromatic ring between the main chain and the phthalimidyl ring (two rigid groups) showed a higher T g value than PA-8, which was without an amino acid moiety, since the phthalimidyl ring bonded directly to the main chain. The presence of a rigid aromatic ring in PA-7 made the side group more rigid and consequently, of higher T g value. It is known that T g increases with an increase in size of the rigid substituents due to the increase in the barrier to rotation around the backbone bonds. In PA-8, there is only one rigid substituent, the phthalimidyl group bonded directly to the main chain, and the T g value is lower than that for PA-7, which includes the p-aminobenzoic residue. These low values of T g permit a higher processability compared with other fully aromatic poly(imides) containing two Si atoms in the main chain, as previously described by the present authors. 27

On the other hand, it is possible to avoid the effect of molecular weight in the T g values due to the fact that all polymers showed similar values of η inh, and demonstrated the oligomeric nature of moderate molecular weight.

Table 3 shows the thermal decomposition temperatures (TDT), taken when polymers lose 10% of their weight. It has been pointed out that a polymer is considered as thermostable when the weight loss is less than 10% at 400°C. From this point of view, only PA-8 can be described as thermostable, and having a rigid and non-aliphatic structure. Surprisingly, although PA-7 did not show thermostable behavior according to the definition despite its aromatic nature, its TDT value was relatively high (370°C).

For PA-1, PA-2 and PA-4, the TDT values were relatively similar and it is possible to observe a tendency in the sense that when the side group of the amino acid is increased, the TDT values decrease. The same tendency occurs in PA-3, PA-5 and PA-6, but with lower TDT values. In general, the increase in volume of side chains of the amino acid residues decreases the TDT value, despite the main chain being the same for all polymers. The lack of symmetry and the length of side chain of the amino acids seem to have a great influence on the thermal stability of these PAs. However, the (imide-amide) group and the polarity of the Si–C bond allow high TDT values to be obtained in general,.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Oligomeric silicon-containing poly(amide)s derived from phthalic anhydride, α-amino acids and 5-amino-isophthalic acid, were synthesized and characterized. Six α-amino acids plus p-aminobenzoic acid and bis(4-aminophenyl)diphenylsilane were used in the synthetic process. Furthermore, a poly(amide) derived from phthalic anhydride and 5-amino-isophthalic acid, and the same diamine was obtained. Polymers were soluble in polar aprotic solvents, with some of them also being soluble in other solvents such as m-cresol and THF, showing an increase in solubility.

Regarding the T g values, in general, it was found that when the side chain of the amino acids was increased, the T g values decreased; low values of this parameter were obtained when the amino acids l-leucine, l-isoleucine and l-phenylalanine were included in the side chain.

The thermogravimetric analysis showed that poly(amide) PA-8, without an amino acid moiety, had high thermostability, and a tendency was found in the sense that when the side group of the amino acid moiety was increased, a decrease in the TDT values was observed. In general, the lack of symmetry and the length of the side chain influenced the thermal stability of these polymers.

In general, the inclusion of amino acids moiety in the side chain of these poly(amides) increased the solubility maintaining a relatively high thermal stability. In some poly(amides), which include amino acids with high aliphatic content, low T g values were obtained; these can improve their processability.
